DataElement.preferredName: Induction Therapeutic Procedure Accomplishment Complete Remission Required Cycle Count
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The total number of cycles of induction therapy that were required to achieve complete remission.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Induction Therapeutic Procedure Accomplishment Complete Remission Required
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The act of bringing about something._An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process._Something that has been achieved or completed successfully._The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment._Required; necessary, not optional.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The act of bringing about something.:An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.definition: The act of bringing about something.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

Property.preferredDefinition: Something that has been achieved or completed successfully.:The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.:Required; necessary, not optional.

Concepts.definition: Something that has been achieved or completed successfully.
The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.
Something that is a necessary condition; something that is obligatory.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process._An event or sequence of events that constitute round or succession of observable phenomena, recurring usually at regular or approximately regular time intervals and in the same sequence._To determine the number or amount of something; the result of this activity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A natural number greater than 1 and less than 3 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of one and one.

Concepts.definition: A natural number greater than 1 and less than 3 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of one and one.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The smallest natural number and quantity it denotes: a single entity, unit, or object.

Concepts.definition: The smallest natural number and quantity it denotes: a single entity, unit, or object.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Integer::3 Greater Than or Equal To

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Integer::3 Greater Than or Equal To
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::3: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.

Concepts.definition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.

A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.:An event or sequence of events that constitute round or succession of observable phenomena, recurring usually at regular or approximately regular time intervals and in the same sequence.:To determine the number or amount of something; the result of this activity.

Concepts.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.
An event or sequence of events that constitute a round or succession of observable phenomena, recurring usually at regular or approximately regular time intervals and in the same sequence.
Determining the number or amount of something.
